notesStmt.note: BBWW performed at Newport, Rhode Island, June 26, 1895. W. A. Paxton (1837-1907) was one of Omaha's leading entrepreneurs involved in cattle, stockyards, wholesale groceries, land, and politics. The Paxton-Gallagher business became renowned for its line of wholesale groceries, including Butternut coffee. The Paxton & Gallagher Wholesale Grocery Company was founded in 1879 by William Paxton and Benjamin Gallagher. Paxton was being pursued as a potential investor in The Shoshone Irrigation Company but later decided against investing [See Bonner, pp18, 31]. According to Bonner, Paxton and his group objected to Hymer. Creighton is likely John A. Creighton (1831-1907), pioneer businessman and philanthropist from Omaha, Nebraska, who founded Creighton University, owned a railroad company, and was Vice-President of the First National Bank of Omaha. William E. Hymer (~1853-1933) was one of the early members of the Shoshone Land and Irrigation Company. Dennis Cunningham and Jerry Ryan would not contribute much in the way of money to the project. Dennis Cunningham was one of the shareholders of the company organized March 20, 1895, which later would be named the Shoshone Land and Irrigation Company [See Bonner, pp13, 31, 70, 72]. Jerry Ryan was an engineer that George T. Beck sent with Laban Hillberry (or Hillsberry) to discover if the Shoshone River could be brought around south of the mountain to irrigate a large area of the Basin. Ryan would also become a shareholder in the Shoshone Land and Irrigation Company formed in 1895.

The Buffalo Bill Wild West and Congress of Rough Riders of the World. Col. W. F. Cody (Buffalo Bill), President.
Nate Salsbury, Vice-Pres't and Manager.
John M. Burke, . . . General Manager.
Albert E. Scheible, . . . Business Manager.
Jule Keen, . . . Treasurer.
div1.p:
Yours recdreceived. I have been so over worked could not write you as fully & as often as I would like to— Alger expects to start west the 1st of July. And is in hopes of takeingtaking two or three Boston men with him. George we have got to get some one with money into it. If Paxton and Creighton2 would go in $50,000 will open up the the 25000 acre tract. after that it will be easy sailing. I can put Heckerts outfit to work And commence work but I cantcan't carry the whole scheme I will help you all I can. But George I cantcan't put up for Hymer-Cunningham Ryan & all— Now Cunningham. Ryan— & others who dontdon't put up must fish

or cut bait. If this work is to be commenced— I cantcan't start in & do it all— Hymer can be let out as Manager. If Paxton & Creighton object to him— Keep some one local to go up there & start things. A Mr. Hake & Bro3 two good men with money wants to go into something they are at Sheridan I am sure they would like to go into this—
But if this is to commence this Summer some you and Alger will have to put your shoulder to the wheel. And call a meeting & reorganize. Those who cantcan't ante drop out—

back.note: Note 1: Buffalo Bill's Wild West performed at Newport, Rhode Island, June 26, 1895.

Note 2: "Creighton" is likely John A. Creighton (1831-1907), pioneer businessman and philanthropist from Omaha, Nebraska, who founded Creighton University, owned a railroad company, and was Vice-President of the First National Bank of Omaha.
Note 3: "A Mr. Hake & Bro" are not identified.
